Title: Developmental Pediatrics Appointment.
definition: "Follow up with a developmental medical provider is recommended. This allows for follow-up of the interventions elected, examination of diagnosis, and answering questions about educational and therapeutic choices.  A developmental medical provider can closely examine medical aspects that may also be present. This may also be an opportunity for families to ask questions that may have come up since this visit. A follow-up appointment can be made by calling Kirch Developmental Services Center at 585-275-2986."

Title: Developmental Pediatrics Appointment.
definition: "Continue regular follow up here at Kirch with a developmental pediatrician/NP.  We would like to continue monitoring [[FNAME]]'s progress and advise [[HISHERTHEIR]] family as [[HESHETHEY]] grows.  How often [[HESHETHEY]] should be seen should be determined by family and the medical provider.  A follow-up appointment can be made by calling Kirch Developmental Services Center at 585-275-2986."

Title: Developmental Pediatrics Appointment.
definition: "[[FNAME]] presents with more than one potential developmental issue and testing today is somewhat mixed.  In order to monitor [[FNAME]]'s ***, I would recommend that [[FNAME]] continue to be followed by a developmental medical provider who has experience working with children with ***. I believe it would be helpful to get a second â€œeyes onï¿½? from another Kirch staff member for a second opinion.  It is not necessary to repeat today's testing at that time."

Title: Psychology Parent Conference.
definition: "I recommend that [[FNAME]]ï¿½s {parent/caregiver:28140} schedule an appointment to meet with me on the same day as [[HE]] meets with a developmental medical provider at Kirch. I would prefer that the medical provider meet with [[FNAME]] and his {parent/caregiver:28140} first, after which I will talk with the developmental pediatrician in order to further clarify [[FNAME]]'s diagnosis."

Title: Coordinated Adult Health Care.
definition: "I discussed with [[FNAME]]'s {parent/caregiver:28140}  the importance of connecting [[FNAME]] with a health care provider that can provide continuity as [[HE]] transitions to the adult health care system. One option could include the Culver Medical Group, which is affiliated with the University of Rochester Medical Center. More information can be obtained by calling (585) 654-5432 or going to their website at https://www.urmc.rochester.edu/primary-care/practices/culver-medical-group.aspx. "

Title: Pediatric Neurology Appointment.
definition: "[[FNAME]] demonstrated motor and vocal tics during todayï¿½s evaluation that appear consistent with a diagnosis of Touretteï¿½s syndrome. I recommend that [[FNAME]]ï¿½s {parent/caregiver:28140} discuss these tic behaviors with [[FNAME]]ï¿½s primary care physician and inquire about referrals for local providers who can provide a detailed neurological assessment related to these behaviors."

Title: Monitoring and Intervention for ADHD.
definition:
"At present, [[FNAME]]ï¿½s ADHD symptoms appear to be interfering with [[HIS]] functioning at school and at home. Considering the potential for symptoms to negatively impact functioning in the future, we recommend that the family seek individualized treatment to target specific areas of need. For [[FNAME]], this may incorporate the following elements: 

Coordination with Specialists. The family was encouraged to discuss this report with their primary care provider, therapist, and other specialists involved in monitoring behavior.
Behavioral Intervention and Parent Training. Based on observation and parent report, [[FNAME]] demonstrates improved focus and is more successful in the context of structured activities (e.g., classroom). This can be difficult for families, as children with this profile often display more prominent symptoms at home, as compared to at school. As such, for many families, we recommend working with a psychologist or psychiatrist who can coordinate behavioral strategies at home to help address symptoms of ADHD. This professional should involve [[FNAME]]ï¿½s parents both in the identification of therapy goals and in the implementation of behavioral intervention, to ensure consistency of treatment strategies across settings. 
Social Skills Groups. Considering [[FNAME]]ï¿½s difficulties sustaining appropriate peer interactions and developing friendships, [[HE]] may benefit from participation in social skills groups. Group-based learning would be especially suited for [[FNAME]], as it provides ongoing learning opportunities and takes advantage of [[HIS]] inherent social motivation. Ideally, these groups should teach concrete rules for social interaction and include a combination of direct instruction and practice. 
Medication Consultation. Many children show significant ADHD symptom improvement in response to consistent behavioral intervention. Others may show some improvement, but continue to present with clinically significant symptoms over time. As such, [[FNAME]]ï¿½s family may wish to consider consulting with [[HIS]] pediatrician to explore the potential role of medication in addressing [[FNAME]]ï¿½s ADHD symptoms. Ongoing monitoring of [[FNAME]]ï¿½s behavior at home and school, both on and off medication, is strongly recommended to comprehensively evaluate medication benefits and potential side effects. In addition, frequent communication among the prescribing physician, [[FNAME]]ï¿½s family, and school staff, is recommended.

	Additional resources are available on the Kirch website at: 	http://www.Golisano.urmc.edu/kirch
"

Title: Mental Health System Utilization.
definition:
"[[FNAME]]ï¿½s {parent/caregiver:28140} and I discussed the importance of determining the appropriate system for accessing services and supports for [[FNAME]], and I strongly encouraged [[HIS]] {parent/caregiver:28140}  to review the Office of Mental Health (OMH) guidelines. I recommend that [[FNAME]]ï¿½s {parent/caregiver:28140} review the following web-sites and discuss potential next steps with [[HIS]] team of educators and health care providers:
New York State OMH Guidelines - https://www.omh.ny.gov/omhweb/guidance/hcbs/html/section_500_1.htm
Documentation for Waiver - https://www.omh.ny.gov/omhweb/guidance/hcbs/html/section_800.htm
"

Title: Behavioral Supports for Families Clinic (BIFF).
definition: "The Behavior Supports for Families Program is run through the Kirch clinic that teaches caregivers about how to take data on their childï¿½s behavior, figure out the functions of their behavior, and use parent-implemented behavioral interventions. A therapist meets individually with caregivers once a week for 6-16 weeks (depending on the family's needs) and teaches them about behavioral interventions using a structured curriculum. [[FNAME]]ï¿½s {parent/caregiver:28140} could learn about the basics of behavior, prevention strategies, rewarding positive behaviors, using visual supports and daily schedules, increasing compliance, how to use planned ignoring and time out, and how to teach new skills. Although a structured curriculum is utilized, the program is individualized to the unique needs of each child and family. Should [[FNAME]]ï¿½s {parent/caregiver:28140} be interested in this program, they can contact our intake coordinator at 585-275-2986."

Title: Incredible Years:
definition: "People's Inc. offers free training designed to teach parents who have children with special needs to foster positive relationships with their children, improve childrenï¿½s compliance and cooperation, decrease negative behaviors at home and develop social skills. More information can be obtained by calling Shannon Bianco at (716) 880-3826 or going to http://www.people-inc.org/children_services_home"

Title: Feeding Clinic.
definition: "[[FNAME]]'s {parent/caregiver:28140} reported significant concerns about feeding.  In particular, [[FNAME]] demonstrates [an insistence on multiple, specific routines being followed prior to eating and eats only a limited number of food items, ***]. In addition, [[HE]] eats limited food while at school. Thus, I would like to refer [[FNAME]] to the Pediatric Feeding Disorders Program.  The first visit should include an initial evaluation with a behavioral specialist in feeding, as well as a consultation with a dietician.  Initial assessment generally involves a nutritional assessment with Brianne Schmidt, RD, and behavioral feeding assessment with Dr. Kimberly Brown.  Evaluation can be scheduled by calling (585) 275-2986 and requesting feeding team appointment."

Title: Feeding Treatment.
definition:
"[[FNAME]]'s {parent/caregiver:28140} reported that [[HE]] eats a very limited number of food items. There are two potential ways in which [[FNAME]] and [[HIS]] family could access feeding treatment through our team.

            (1) Parent Support for Feeding Behavior. There is an ongoing research study, which focuses on feeding and mealtime behaviors. You can call Lisa Snow at (585) 275-2986 to inquire further.
            (2) Pediatric Feeding Disorders Program. The first visit should include an initial evaluation with a behavioral specialist in feeding, as well as a consultation with a dietician.  Initial assessment generally involves a nutritional assessment with Brianne Schmidt, RD, and behavioral feeding assessment with Dr. Kimberly Brown.  Evaluation can be scheduled by calling (585) 275-2986.
"

Title: Sleep Clinic.
definition: "I would recommend that [[FNAME]]'s family contact Pediatric Sleep Medicine Services to address [[FNAME]]'s current sleep difficulties.  This service focuses on treating sleep issues and sleep related breathing disorders in children and adolescents. It is a multidisciplinary clinic that involves specialists in a variety of areas including those from Pediatric Ear Nose and Throat or Craniofacial Surgery, Pediatric Medicine, Dentistry, Audiology and Speech and Language.  To make an initial appointment, please call the intake coordinator at (585) 340-8949 for an informational meeting. The Pediatric Sleep Medicine Services of the Strong Sleep Disorders Center is located at: 2180 South Clinton Ave., Rochester, NY 14618"

Title: Melatonin.
definition: "We also discussed the use of melatonin for sleep problems. Melatonin is a brain hormone that regulates sleep. A synthetic version is sold over the counter as a non-FDA regulated nutritional supplement. It may be available in liquid, rapid-melt, tablet, and long-acting formulas, and is found at many pharmacies or vitamin shops.  Controlled studies have shown that doses of 0.5- 6.0 mg given 30-60 minutes before bedtime can help children with autism and other developmental disabilities fall asleep more quickly.  Extended Release, (also called Controlled Release) melatonin swallow capsules may reduce night waking.  If chosen as a treatment, sleep patterns should be monitored, and a product without other vitamins or added supplement ingredients is recommended.  Sleep improves most when environmental and behavioral treatments are used in combination with Melatonin. Medication, over the counter or otherwise prescribed, should always be discussed with [[FNAME]]'s primary care provider first."

Title: Speech and Language Evaluation.
definition: "[[FNAME]] demonstrated presumed difficulties with expressive and pragmatic language during todayï¿½s evaluation, which is consistent with parent and teacher report. In particular, [[FNAME]] communicated [using brief verbal responses and he frequently indicated that he did not know the answer to questions; included recurrent grammatical errors and odd verbal responses, ***].  It is possible that [[HIS]] verbal presentation was related to oppositionality, but we would like to better characterize [[HIS]] language abilities, in case there is an underlying language impairment.  As such, it is recommended that [[FNAME]] obtain a comprehensive speech and language evaluation to further clarify their expressive and pragmatic abilities. An appointment with Dr. Dawn Vogler-Elias, who is a speech language pathologist at the Kirch Developmental Services Center, can be made by calling (585) 275-2986. The results of such an evaluation could help guide ongoing treatment planning as part of [[FNAME]]'s individualized education plan (IEP)."

Title: Autism Elopement Study.
definition:
"[[FNAME]]ï¿½s {parent/caregiver:28140} reported a history of concerns regarding [[FNAME]] wandering and bolting when out in the community. I believe that [[FNAME]] and [[HIS]]  {parent/caregiver:28140} would be a good candidate for the Elopement in ASD study here at the University of Rochester Medical Center. More information about this study can be found on-line at:

https://www.urmc.rochester.edu/childrens-hospital/developmental-disabilities/research/treatment-studies/elopement-in-children-with-asd.aspx
"

Title: Intervention for Hand Mannerisms.
definition:
"[[FNAME]] engages in motor hand mannerisms that have the potential to impact [[HIS]] social functioning, particularly as [[HE]] gets older. If this continues to be a concern for [[FNAME]]ï¿½s family, we recommend an intervention plan to address these behaviors, which may include the following elements:

Self-monitoring and reinforcement program. For many children, self-monitoring is the first step toward helping them decrease their target behavior. To increase [[FNAME]]ï¿½s awareness of [[HIS]] repetitive hand mannerisms, a reinforcement program should be implemented where both [[FNAME]] and an adult (e.g., parent, school personnel) keep track of each time [[FNAME]] engages in the behavior. If the frequency of [[FNAME]]ï¿½s hand movements falls below a pre-set criterion, [[HE]] receives points, which can then be exchanged for a reward. This criterion should be determined by [[FNAME]]ï¿½s initial rate of behavior and then lowered over time. For example, if [[FNAME]] initially uses hand mannerisms 5 times per hour, the criterion should be set at 6 times per hour (to ensure success and help [[FNAME]] gain momentum), and then faded incrementally 
Redirection to an incompatible response. [[FNAME]] should be taught a variety of behaviors that are incompatible with motor movements, such as putting [[HIS]] hands in [[HIS]] pockets and clasping [[HIS]] hands in [[HIS]] lap. [[FNAME]] would likely benefit from visual cues (e.g., a card on [[HIS]] desk that says ï¿½hands down,ï¿½ colored bracelets on [[HIS]] wrists) and gestural reminders (e.g., the teacher putting her hands together) to redirect [[HIM]] to a more appropriate behavior 
Competing items. Children with motor behaviors often benefit from the provision of a physical object (e.g., stress ball, silly putty) that competes with the mannerisms. Consider giving [[FNAME]] access to these types of objects in class, for transitions (e.g., walking in the hall), and when [[HE]] is out in the community, as well as during times when [[HE]] is most likely to engage in the behavior, such as when [[HE]] is excited or anxious
Scheduled time to engage in stereotypy. As it is often difficult to completely eliminate motor mannerisms, [[FNAME]] would benefit from the provision of specific times and/or places (e.g., [[HIS]] bedroom) in which [[HE]] is permitted to engage in these movements. In school, [[HIS]] teachers may consider giving him a ï¿½hall pass,ï¿½ which [[HE]] can use to take a walk or go to the bathroom 
Rob Rice, Ph.D. specializes in treating repetitive behaviors. His practice is located in Pittsford, and he can be reached at (585) 727-4811
"

Title: Ongoing Therapy.
definition: "I recommend ongoing therapy with [[FNAME]]ï¿½s current provider. Based on todayï¿½s evaluation [[FNAME]] meets criteria for ***, but there are additional diagnostic questions that deserve ongoing monitoring.  These behaviors deserve further observation over time.  Therapeutically, [[FNAME]] would likely continue to benefit from behavioral and cognitive behavioral approaches aimed at increasing [[FNAME]]'s behavioral flexibility, tolerance for others breaking rules and getting in their space.  [[HE]] would also likely benefit from social skills training to improve interactions with peers."

Title: Individual Therapy.
definition:
"I encourage [[FNAME]]ï¿½s family to seek behavioral/mental health treatment for [[HIM]] as well.  While medication can be a helpful adjunct to treatment, it does not explicitly teach a child alternate and more appropriate behavior, nor does it help parents with managing behavior problems they have to deal with on a regular basis. Working with an individual therapist can help children to recognize and respond to emotions in a productive way.  [[FNAME]]ï¿½s {parent/caregiver:28140} can learn strategies to support their child's emotional development and behavioral strategies to reduce negative behaviors. Strategies to identify a child therapist include:


A. Contacting the family insurance provider to determine in-network therapists
B.  Utilizing web-based resources available through the family insurance plan or publicly available (ie. Http://therapists.psychologytoday.com/rms/prof_search.php) to search for local therapists with the needed experience.
C.  Meeting with, and interviewing several therapists to find a "good fit."

Additional resources are available on the Kirch website at: http://www.Golisano.urmc.edu/Kirch"

Title: Anxiety Evaluation and Intervention.
definition:
"During the evaluation, [[FNAME]] and [[HIS]] caregivers reported that [[HE]] experiences various symptoms of anxiety, including ***. Considering [[FNAME]]ï¿½s distress in these situations and the potential for anxiety to negatively impact the functioning of [[HIS]] family and [[HIM]], a comprehensive psychological evaluation is recommended at this time. This evaluation should further explicate the nature and severity of [[FNAME]]ï¿½s anxiety-related symptoms, including identifying situations in which anxiety is likely to occur and the extent to which these symptoms interfere with [[HIS]] functioning. The results of this evaluation should be used to inform a treatment approach and intervention goals. For example, Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is an individualized, skill-based approach for treating anxiety disorders and other difficulties.
"

Title: Evaluation and Intervention for Mood.
definition: "Given [[FNAME]]'s significant emotional dysregulation (i.e., angry outbursts, mood swings, aggression), more mood-specific psychological evaluation is indicated to determine the nature and severity of [[HIS]] mood disturbance. Ideally, the results of this evaluation would be used to create a treatment plan that focuses on increasing [[FNAME]]'s coping skills, and improving [[HIS]] frustration tolerance. Some suggestions are provided here that could be incorporated into [[HIS]] treatment plan and/or used at home."

Title: Instruction in Emotion Identification and Coping Skills.
definition:
"Direct instruction in emotion identification, including the use of visual supports (e.g., a feelings thermometer)
Teaching concrete strategies for managing negative emotions in the moment (e.g., relaxation training, coping thoughts). Relaxation scripts for children are available online at https://depts.washington.edu/hcsats/PDF/TF-%20CBT/pages/4%20Emotion%20Regulation%20Skills/Client%20Handouts/Relaxation/Relaxation%20Script%20for%20Younger%20Children.pdf
Practice for using these skills both in therapy and in naturalistic settings 
Working with [[FNAME]]ï¿½s family to teach them behavioral strategies to help ï¿½coachï¿½ [[FNAME]] during moments of frustration 
Examples of structured curricula for teaching emotion identification and frustration tolerance skills are listed below: 
The Incredible 5-Point Scale, by Kari Dunn Buron and Mitzi Curtis
A 5 is Against the Law! by Kari Dunn Buron"

Title: Frustration Tolerance Program.
definition:
"This type of program is recommended to promote frustration tolerance through incremental changes and positive reinforcement and should be highly individualized and systematic.   

A reinforcement system chould be implemented, through which [[FNAME]] tracks [[HIS]] behavior (e.g., outbursts, task refusal) with help from adults and receives praise and external reinforcement (e.g., preferred activities) for tolerating frustrating situations.
Initially, [[FNAME]] should be exposed to low-frustration situations (e.g., easy tasks, small change in his routine) and should be highly reinforced for tolerating those situations.
When the first step has been established, the goal shifts to tolerating increasingly frustrating situations (e.g., difficult demands, going somewhere [[HE]] is not expecting), with accompanying reinforcement. These goals could be targeted both in therapy and also in naturalistic settings (e.g., home, community)
"

Title: Strategies to improve transitions.
definition:
"Keep [[FNAME]]ï¿½s schedule consistent and use visual supports (e.g., activity schedules) to prepare [[HIM]] for [[HIS]] day. These schedules can also be used to provide a visual warning for when [[HE]] will transition between settings.
Provide warnings before transitions and use timers to signal the amount of time [[HE]] has left during preferred activities.
[[FNAME]] would benefit from clearly and consistent expectations among [[HIS]] environments, including similar responsibilities (e.g., clearing his plate, dressing himself) and similar expectations for what [[HE]] will do with assistance and what [[HE]] should do independently.
Intersperse easy and difficult demands to reduce [[NAME]]'s refusal to follow directions. For example [[HE]] may first be asked to bring [[HIS]] plate to the sink before being asked to clean up [[HIS]] toys.
Maintaining a calm environment (or providing [[HIM]] a secure space to calm down) may help alleviate transition-related stress.
Implement a reward chart, wherein [[FNAME]] receives points or stickers for following directions. These points can then be exchanged for toys or privileges (e.g., extra TV time, favorite dinner).
"

Title: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT).
definition:
"[[FNAME]] would likely benefit from participation in regular therapy sessions focused on the development of coping skills, social problem solving, and building up a tolerance for when things do not go as planned. 


Concrete thinking and behavioral rigidity often interfere in [[FNAME]]ï¿½s daily life, at home and could presumably interfere more at school as social and organizational demands become more complex. This could increasingly interfere with [[HIS]] ability to function in social and academic settings. [[FNAME]]ï¿½s {parent/caregiver:28140} understand [[FNAME]] well and provide [[HIM]] with a great deal of support with how to cope with changes. They also provide [[FNAME]] with advanced warning about changes, so that [[HE]] can prepare for situations on the horizon. Although [[FNAME]]ï¿½s {parent/caregiver:28140}ï¿½ support is helpful and instrumental in [[HIS]] success, [[FNAME]] will need to internalize these coping skills so that [[HE]] can enlist them without prompting from others. 

CBT is a type of therapy that is designed to help improve a child's moods, anxiety, and behavior by examining confused or distorted patterns of thinking. Therapy sessions tend to be structured. The therapist teaches the child that thoughts cause feelings and moods, which in turn can influence behavior. One of the goals of CBT is to teach the child to identify harmful thought patterns that lead to depressed mood or anxious feelings. The therapist then helps the child replace this thinking with thoughts that result in more appropriate feelings and behaviors. Research shows that CBT can be effective in treating a wide range of conditions, especially symptoms of anxiety and depression. 
I recommended the family consider cognitive-behavioral therapy for treatment related to [[FNAME]]ï¿½s symptoms of [anxiety and rigid thinking and patterns of behavior, ***]. 

CBT is a specific type of individual therapy. It is evidence-based treatment for anxiety that looks at the relationships between thoughts, feelings, and behavior. A CBT therapist may use techniques such as coping strategies, relaxation, and biofeedback training. Strategies for identifying a child CBT therapist include: 

Contacting the family insurance provider to determine in-network therapists
Utilizing web-based resources available through the family insurance plan or publicly available (i.e., http://therapists.psychologytoday.com/rms/prof_search.php) to search for local therapists who are trained in CBT. 
Meeting with, and interviewing several therapists to find a "good fit." 
Additional resources are available on the Kirch website at: 
 https://www.urmc.rochester.edu/childrens-hospital/developmental-disabilities/services/kirch/Family-Resource-Directory/Mental-Health.aspx
"

Title: Consultation for Targeted Behavior Change.
definition:
"[[FNAME]] and his mother both provided me with information about the level of support [[FNAME]] seeks and obtains with his writing and with planning related to academic activities while he is on campus at St. Johnï¿½s. They both commented on how certain social situations are uncomfortable or awkward on a recurring basis.  I recommend that [[FNAME]] work with a provider to develop a focused plan for increasing his level of functional independence related to academic activities and to develop effective coping strategies to address behavioral rigidity concerns. To that end, I am happy to meet with [[FNAME]], his family, or each of them separately for the duration of the summer to help facilitate this change process. Alternatively, I can work with [[FNAME]] and his family to determine an appropriate referral in the community here.
"

Title: Social Skills Training.
definition:
"  I would recommend direct instruction to support [[FNAME]]'s development and use of social skills (e.g., social interaction, personal boundaries, social problem solving).  This should incorporate a Teach-Model-Rehearse-Reinforce format.  Training in social skills incorporates instructional strategies for developing social competence and social problem solving.  The resources listed below provide a list of solid instructional strategies for use with a wide range of students:

Development and use of Carol Gray's social stories and comic strip conversations for use at home as well as throughout the school day.  Social stories allow for direct teaching of social knowledge that some students do not acquire incidentally.  Comic strip conversations are a vehicle for exploring problem solving as well as scripting language for specific circumstances/occasions.  A member of [[FNAME]]'s team (e.g., psychologist, speech language pathologist, special education teacher) can be identified as a "point person" for developing, teaching and rehearsing the social stories.  They should be tracked with specific record keeping procedures.  Information about social stories can be found at www.thegraycenter.org
McGinnis, Ellen and Goldstein, Arnold P.  (1997). Champaign, Illinois: Research Press.  Includes checklists for families and schools to assess skills as well as specific lessons to teach skills referenced in checklists.  This reference can be used as an informal assessment tool, which will help identify instructional priorities.
SOCCSS (Situation, Options, Consequences, Choices, Strategies, Simulation) program can be used as a vehicle for teaching social problem solving skills.  This program follows a consistent, systematic format; incorporates the use of actual events as a vehicle for instruction; and utilizes visual supports in the form of a graphical organizer.  Information about SOCCSS can be found in the following reference:  Myles, Brenda Smith., Trautman, Melissa L., and Schelvan, Ronda L.  (2004). Shawnee Mission, KS: Autism Asperger Publishing Company.
"

Title: Social Skills Group.
definition: "[[FNAME]] does not currently have close relationships with same-age peers, so it will be important for [[HIM]] to practice skills learned from [[HIS]] special education program. It is recommended that [[FNAME]]'s consider enrolling [[FNAME]] in the Program for the Education and Enrichment of Relational Skills (PEERS), which is an evidence-based group therapy for adolescents with pervasive developmental disorders and their caregivers. The program runs for 14 weeks and includes group sessions during which teens learn and practice different social skills; the {parent/caregiver:28140} meet concurrently, but separately, to learn how to support their teens with generalizing the skills taught during group. This treatment model is implemented at Strong Behavioral Health Child and Adolescent Psychiatry, so it is recommended that [[FNAME]]ï¿½s {parent/caregiver:28140} call this clinic at (585) 279-7800 to learn about PEERS."

Title: Women's Group.
definition: "The Womenï¿½s Group is a group that helps young women with developmental disabilities (ages 18-30) discover and nurture their passions in life while building lasting friendships. Active in the community, the group also seeks to bolster membersï¿½ socialization skills. Contact Elli Assiobo-Tipoh for more information at (585) 719-3435 or eassiobo@people-inc.org."

Title: Recreation.
definition:
"[[FNAME]] should develop and participate in enjoyable recreational activities.  These activities could provide [[FNAME]] with increased opportunities for socialization with peers.  In addition, these recreational settings can be used for incidental teaching of social skills that are actively taught in school and through more formal social skills programs.  Examples include religious organization youth groups, YMCA, Park and Recreation activities as well as school level interest groups such as computers, chess or others.  [[FNAME]]ï¿½s {parent/caregiver:28140} are encouraged to limit the amount of TV/videos a child sees and to monitor for content.  I strongly encourage use of parental controls on family computers. For additional recommendations for screen time, please refer to the following guidelines provided by the American Academy of Pediatrics: https://www.aap.org/en-us/advocacy-and-policy/aap-health-initiatives/pages/media-and-children.aspx 
"

Title: Sports.
definition:
"Rochester Special Hockey: The Rochester Special Hockey is an organization that specializes in providing training in the game of ice hockey for individuals with developmental disabilities. Teams are geared to individual needs with an emphasis on sportsmanship and learning to interact with others.  They are a 501c3 Not for Profit volunteer organization with support coming from all our families, both as coaches, trainers, drivers and most of all fans. More information about Rochester Special Hockey can be found at www.rochesterspecialhockey.org or by calling (585) 723-8896
"

Title: Starbridge TIES Program.
definition:
"[[FNAME]] may benefit from participation in the TIES program. Together Including Every Student (TIES) promotes the participation of students with developmental disabilities in extracurricular and community activities by creating effective, natural support provided by trained student volunteers.  To determine whether [[FNAME]] is eligible for participation in this program, please contact:

Web address: http://www.starbridgeinc.org/how-we-can-help/community-transformation/ties-together-including-every-student
Phone number: (585) 546-1700
"

Title: Special Education and Related Services.
definition: "[[FNAME]]’s {parent/caregiver:28140} reported that [[FNAME]] *** an Individualized Education Plan (IEP) at this time. It will be important for [[FNAME]] to have an educational team to coordinate services and develop a ***. It is recommended that [[FNAME]]’s {parent/caregiver:28140} call their school district to request a Committee for Special Education (CSE) meeting to determine [[FNAME]]’s eligibility for special education and related services. Per {parent/caregiver:28140}’s report, [[FNAME]] is having a difficult time in the school setting.  A Functional Behavioral Analysis (FBA) may help to identify specific problems, situations in which they are most likely to occur and to develop strategies and supports to help [[FNAME]] be more successful while continuing to develop independence. Based on [[FNAME]]’s individual needs, the CSE will make a determination about the type, amount, and location of service delivery. "

Title: Multi-Disciplinary Educational Evaluation.
definition: "I would recommend that [[FNAME]] receive an evaluation of [[HIS]] current intellectual abilities, achievement level, receptive, expressive, and pragmatic language abilities, adaptive behavior, and social-emotional behaviors. This will provide critical information as it relates to educational planning and determining [[HIS]] eligibility for Developmental Disabilities Regional Office case management and Medicaid Waiver services."

Title: Special Education Considerations:
definition:
"Educational and behavioral interventions for children need to be individualized to meet their needs. Several principals need to be considered:

Children should be educated in the least restrictive environment when possible.
Students with *** often benefit from predictability and routine.
Consider a teach- model-rehearse approach. 
The social skills curriculum needs to reflect the child’s language level.
Children with *** may have impairments in imitation and understanding inference
The educational team would likely benefit from training and support from professional staff to meet the child’s programmatic needs.
Children benefit from reinforcement of communication and social goals outside of school or therapy hours.
"

Title: Components of Effective Treatment.
definition:
"[[FNAME]]’s family should contact their CPSE/CSE chair with results of this evaluation and should use this report as documentation of the diagnosis.  The Committee may need to re-convene to modify and intensify services.   Classification based on a diagnosis of an autism spectrum disorder would be appropriate and may help to describe educational needs. A body of research has accumulated about effective treatment for children with autism spectrum disorders. A general list of components of an educational program is presented below. How these are implemented is best determined by people who work with [[FNAME]] closely. 



Comprehensive curriculum focusing on teaching a wide range of skills, including attention to the environment, imitation, comprehension and production of language, functional communication, toy play, and peer interaction.
Highly supportive teaching environments structured to maximize attention to instructional activities and to facilitate the use of skills in everyday settings.
Emphasis on providing children with predictability and routine.
Functional behavior analytic approach to assessing and treating behavior problems.
Systematic intervention for facilitating transitions from home to school setting.
Consultation or supervision by a professional with expertise in interventions for children with autism spectrum disorders.
"

Title: Peer Model.
definition: "I would encourage the school team to consider identifying a peer model with strong social and leadership skills, who could provide structure and support for [[FNAME]] during less structured parts of the day, like recess or lunch. One barrier to participation in recess or lunchtime activities may be anxiety around not knowing how to join in.  A positive peer model already involved in these types of activities could demonstrate joining in skills and help [[FNAME]] interact more successfully with classmates."

Title: Educational Placement.
definition:
"Decisions regarding [[FNAME]]’s educational placement should ultimately be informed by the results of his most recent educational evaluation.   In general, [[FNAME]] would benefit from a classroom setting with special education instruction and behavioral supports. [[FNAME]]’s level of functioning suggests that [[HE]] would be well-served in a classroom that incorporates the following characteristics:

Small class size or a small student-to-teacher ratio
Instructional support from a teacher or aide
Organizational support for materials, assignments, and homework
"

Title: General Accommodations to Increase Attention.
definition:
"I would also recommend academic accommodations to support appropriate attention during group instruction, such as:

Preferential seating to help decrease distractions and to accommodate [[HIS]] auditory processing differences.
Repetition of information to enhance encoding and memory of information. Efforts should be made to create an educational environment that is open to requests for repetition of directions.  
[[FNAME]] will likely require structure, consistent adult attention, redirection, encouragement and praise in order to stay on task and perform at [[HIS]] maximal level. 
It could be helpful to work with a behavior specialist to implement a consistent behavior management plan that reinforces attention to task and work completion.
"

Title: Classroom Strategies Related to ADHD.
definition:
"[[FNAME]]’s parents reported several symptoms of ADHD (i.e., distractibility, problems with sustained attention, restlessness, impulsivity), which were most prominent during unstructured situations. Given these difficulties, the following recommendations are provided to help set [[FNAME]] up for success in the classroom and at home. Many of these strategies may already be implemented by classroom staff.

Obtain [[FNAME]]’s eye contact before providing verbal directions 
Use visual checklists for complex and long-term assignments, both to ensure that [[FNAME]] attends to the rules of the assignment and to promote self-monitoring skills
Visual supports (e.g., checklists, graphic organizers, activity schedules) for classroom assignments, homework, and materials (e.g., worksheets, books, calculator) will help promote [[FNAME]]’s time-management and task organization skills. 
Color-coded folders, binders, book covers and bins (e.g., organized by subject) will also be helpful in facilitating [[FNAME]]’s organization of important assignments, handouts, and materials. 
Promote [[FNAME]]’s academic organization and home-based adaptive skills through the use of visual checklists for classroom assignments (particularly complex or long-term projects), personal care routines, and household chores. Complex or multi-step tasks should be broken up into step-by-step components, which [[FNAME]] will check off. Initially, [[FNAME]] may complete these checklists with guidance from [[HIS]] parents and teachers, which can be faded out over time and as [[HE]] becomes more successful in managing [[HIS]] own time and responsibilities. 
Visual checklists and activity schedules will be especially important for helping [[FNAME]] understand behavioral and social expectations during unstructured activities (e.g., lunch, recess). Aim to make these activities as structured as possible to help [[FNAME]] organize [[HIS]] times. For example, [[HE]] may use a personal checklist that outlines the rules of the game to be played
Use chunked instruction, in which information and assignments are broken up into step-by-step components and presented individually. Initially, [[FNAME]] should be encouraged to complete checklists outlining these steps with guidance from a teacher; this support can be faded out over time as [[FNAME]] becomes more successful in managing [[HIS]] own time and responsibilities
Conduct comprehension checks to ensure that [[FNAME]] has paid attention to all the key issues and task expectations
Provide verbal praise for following directions and especially for initiating or completing tasks independently
To provide incentive for appropriate behavior and independent adaptive skills, consider implementing a reward system, through which [[FNAME]] earns points for appropriate behavior (e.g., getting dressed in the morning, completing a list of chores at home, following classroom or house rules). These points may then be traded in for a predetermined reward (e.g., extra recess time, five minutes of a preferred activity). 
Despite [[FNAME]]’s low frustration tolerance in the face of challenging task and language demands, [[HE]] responded well when presented with simple, clear instructions and verbal encouragement. These strategies may help facilitate persistence during difficult tasks at home and at school. Additionally, providing him with initial opportunities to succeed (e.g., with easier items or with help from a teacher) before presenting more difficult items will likely foster [[HIS]] momentum to work and will help increase engagement
Allow preferential seating (e.g., at the front of the class, away from doors and windows) to reduce distractions in the classroom
Provide movement breaks throughout the day, during which [[FNAME]] can get up from [[HIS]] seat. To minimize disruption, these breaks can be incorporated into daily classroom activities (e.g., taking the attendance log to the office, watering the plants)
[[FNAME]]’s teachers have reportedly done an excellent job maintaining regular communication with [[HIS]] parents. We recommend that ongoing communication continue, either over the phone or via a notebook or email. Check-ins on a weekly basis will be essential for adequate monitoring of [[HIS]] ADHD symptoms across settings
"

Title: ADHD Assessment.
definition:
"I provided [[FNAME]]'s {parent/caregiver:28140} with a hard copy of the Vanderbilt ADHD Diagnostic Teacher Rating Scale. I recommended that [[FNAME]]'s {parent/caregiver:28140} give this assessment to one of [[FNAME]]'s school team members in order to help confirm or rule out the possibility of an ADHD diagnosis. The Vanderbilt scale can be found at the following website. 

It is free and available for use by school personnel and healthcare professionals: http://www.brightfutures.org/mentalhealth/pdf/professionals/bridges/adhd.pdf
"

Title: Follow-up Autism Assessment:
definition: "I spoke with [[FNAME]]'s {parent/caregiver:28140} about the importance of obtaining autism-specific information from a member of [[FNAME]]'s school team who knows [[HIM]] well. In order to assist with confirming or ruling out the presence of an autism spectrum disorder, I would like for someone from [[FNAME]]'s school team (preferably, his teacher or counselor) to complete the [***, Asperger Syndrome Diagnostic Scale]. I will obtain a copy of this measure and mail a hard copy of it to [[FNAME]]'s home address; I spoke with [[FNAME]]'s {parent/caregiver:28140} about providing this to a member of his school team to then send back to me at my Kirch mailing address. Receiving information on this measure from a school team member would be a tremendous asset to clarifying his diagnosis."

Title: Assistive Technology Consultation.
definition:
"The report from [[FNAME]]'s {parent/caregiver:28140} and school team indicate that [[FNAME]] has difficulty with hand-writing. Given [[HIS]] high intellectual and academic abilities, [[FNAME]]'s difficulties with hand-writing may prevent [[HIM]] from conveying the full extent of [[HIS]] knowledge during regular assignments and standardized assessments. I would recommend that an assistive technology consultation be sought out in order to determine an alternative way for [[FNAME]] to provide written responses for school-related work. One resource to consider when seeking an assistive technology consultation could be found here:

http://www.monroe2boces.org/exceptionalChildren.cfm?subpage=2282
"

Title: School Counseling Support:
definition: "[[FNAME]] may benefit from regular meetings with a school counselor or psychologist who could help [[HIM]] to utilize coping skills and relaxation techniques in the school setting. These meetings could focus on discussing current sources of anxiety at school and helping [[HIM]] to plan how to use some of the strategies [[HE]] has learned as part of [[HIS]] individual therapy in the community. This may help [[FNAME]] to more effectively modulate [[HIS]] reactions when [[HE]] encounters academic roadblocks or discovers that [[HE]] has made errors in [[HIS]] work.  Over time, a school counselor or psychologist can work to increase [[FNAME]]'s independent initiation of coping and relaxation techniques.  In addition, classroom staff could prompt [[FNAME]] to use these coping and relaxation strategies when [[HE]] appears frustrated or withdrawn. "

Title: Functional Behavioral Assessment:
definition: "In order to address [[FNAME]]'s difficulties with ***, a Functional Behavioral Assessment (FBA) is recommended.  Such an assessment evaluates behaviors that interfere with learning and should include formal assessment of potential behavioral and environmental factors that may contribute to the occurrence of problem behavior.  Intervention recommendations from the FBA should emphasize the use of teaching of desired behavior and reinforcement programs to gradually shape compliant, adaptive and on-task behavior.  Some behavioral plans require consequences to occur in response to undesired behaviors.  Consultation from a clinician with expertise in behavioral assessment and intervention in children with developmental disabilities may be necessary given the intensity of the behavioral concerns.  For behavioral plans to be successful, they must be consistently implemented by all of the adults who interact with a child at home and at school.  Some behaviors are also seen at home, so behavioral support to the family to help modify these behaviors may be necessary from sources outside of the school. "

Title: Functional Behavioral Assessment:
definition: "To address [[FNAME]]’s difficulties with oppositional behavior, work refusal, and tantrums, a Functional Behavioral Analysis (FBA) is recommended.  Such an assessment evaluates behaviors that interfere with learning and should include formal assessment of potential behavioral and environmental factors that may contribute to the occurrence of problem behavior.  Intervention recommendations from the FBA should emphasize the use of teaching of desired behavior and reinforcement programs to gradually shape compliant, adaptive and on-task behavior.  Some behavioral plans require consequences to occur in response to undesired behaviors.  Consultation from a clinician with expertise in behavioral assessment and intervention in children with developmental disabilities may be necessary given the intensity of the behavioral concerns.  For behavioral plans to be successful, they must be consistently implemented by all of the adults who interact with a child at home and at school.  Some behaviors are only seen at home.  Since [[FNAME]] has also shown an escalation of non-compliance and tantrums at home, behavioral support to the family to help modify these behaviors may be necessary from sources outside of the school."

Title: Behavioral Supports at School.
definition:
"[[FNAME]]'s family reports that [[HE]] engages in challenging behaviors at school that seem to interfere is [[HIS]] ability to participate in daily activities.  Thus, the school team, may wish to consider using some of the following behavioral approaches in the classroom to improve participation and decrease challenging behaviors: 

Environmental Controls. Consider the classroom environment. Are there environmental triggers that set off specific challenging behaviors (proximity to certain children or activity areas)? If so, consider moving [[FNAME]] to an area of the classroom that minimizes these triggers. In addition, [[FNAME]] would benefit from a desk in a quiet section of the classroom, in order to help decrease distractions. 

Daily Schedule.. [[FNAME]] may also benefit from a regular daily schedule, so that [[HE]] can see what activities come next. It may be helpful to display [[FNAME]]'s activities in a visual schedule, with pictures that depict each activity. 

Reduced Demands at Difficult Times of Day.  There may be a time of day, when [[FNAME]] has more difficulties (such as in the morning or the afternoon). [[HE]] could be provided with fewer academic demands and shorter work periods during that period of the day. 

Break Work into Smaller Chunks.  [[FNAME]] has trouble sustaining long periods of independent desk work and would benefit from modified work assignments.  Breaking work sheets down into smaller parts, providing visual supports such as checklists that help structure multi-step tasks, visual cues to stop and ask for help would be useful.


Preferred Activities Following Non-preferred Tasks. Activities could be differentiated and identified according to preferred and non-preferred status. [[FNAME]]’s schedule should be developed where non-preferred activities are directly followed by preferred activities. 

Classroom Rules. [[FNAME]] would benefit from the establishment of clear, concise classroom rules that are tailored to [[HIS]] specific needs. For example, some behaviors that have interfered with [[FNAME]]’s success in the classroom include ***. It will be important for all team members to agree on the rules before they are presented to [[FNAME]]. Similarly, all team members should become familiar with these rules and prompt [[HIM]] to follow them in a similar manner across settings. 

Reinforcement System. To increase [[FNAME]]'s more adaptive behaviors, such as following the classroom rules, it may be helpful to implement a reward system. A reinforcement system should incorporate [[FNAME]]'s special interests (e.g., ***) and include rewards that are actually attractive and motivating to [[HIM]]. In order for a reinforcement system to work, it must be implemented consistently by all school personnel. In addition, frequent reminders about what [[HE]] is working for and what [[HE]] must do to earn the rewards will increase the likelihood that the system will be effective. 

Contingency Contract [[FNAME]]’s classroom rules and the associated rewards can be presented to [[HIM]] in the form of a Contingency Contract. This is a document that is drafted jointly by the team and [[FNAME]]. It states behavioral expectations for [[FNAME]] and associated rewards should [[HE]] follow the rules. The contract is discussed in a meeting with [[FNAME]], modified and signed by all parties involved (classroom teachers, [[FNAME]], school psychologist, etc). One benefit of a contingency contract is that it gives [[FNAME]] a more active role in [[HIS]] own behavioral progress. It will also show [[HIM]] that the educational team is working together and that all parties are aware of behavioral expectations and agree to implement the plan. 

Development of Coping Strategies. [[FNAME]] would benefit from the instruction in the development and utilization of appropriate coping strategies and relaxation techniques that can be initiated when [[HE]] shows early warning signs indicating frustration and anxiety. This may help [[FNAME]] to more effectively modulate [[HIS]] reactions when [[HE]] encounters academic roadblocks or discovers that [[HE]] has made errors in [[HIS]] work. Over time, the team can work to increase [[FNAME]]’s independent initiation of relaxation techniques. In addition, classroom staff could prompt [[HIM]] to use these coping and relaxation strategies when [[HE]] opts to take a break from lessons. Adults working with [[FNAME]] should be careful not to prompt [[HIM]] to use these skills independently until they have been learned and mastered by [[HIM]]. Assessment of [[FNAME]]’s level of mastery should be a part of the instructional process."

Title: Social Work (NDBP):
definition: "I encourage [[FNAME]]’s family to contact our social workers at (585) 275-2986 for information about local parent support groups, information, and resources."

Title: Developmental Disabilities Regional Office (DDRO).
definition:
"Children over 3 may be eligible for DDRO case management and Medicaid Waiver services.  To qualify for such services, a child must have a diagnosis of a developmental disability along with documentation of cognitive and/or adaptive deficits. Families should gather reports such as this one to document diagnosis.  Cognitive abilities should be documented by preschool or school age psychological testing.  Adaptive abilities are evaluated in the form of testing such as the Vineland-II or other adaptive behavior scale. 

Access Team contact numbers can be found online at: http://www.opwdd.ny.gov/opwdd_contacts/ddro
Access to Services Resource Booklet: http://www.opwdd.ny.gov/welcome-front-door/resource-booklet 
Family Information Sessions could be helpful for [[FNAME]]'s family as they navigate the application process
"

Title: Kirch Website.
definition:
"I recommended that [[FNAME]]'s family refer to the Kirch Center website and/or Facebook page for additional information about regional services, supports, events, and scientific information that may be of help. These resources can be accessed at the following addresses: 

http://www.Golisano.URMC.edu/Kirch  
https://www.facebook.com/kirchcenter
"

Title: Autism Speaks 100 Days 100 Kit.
definition: "I would recommend that [[FNAME]]'s {parent/caregiver:28140} use The Autism Speaks 100 Day Kit to help structure their next steps in determining [[FNAME]]'s care. The 100 Day Kit was created specifically for newly diagnosed families, to make the best possible use of the 100 days following the diagnosis of autism. The kit contains information and advice collected from trusted and respected experts on autism as well as from parents of children with autism. There is a week-by-week plan for the next 100 days, as well organizational suggestions and forms that caregivers can use to help with the paperwork and phone calls, as they begin to find services for their child.  Please see the following website for detailed information about the kit: http://www.autismspeaks.org/community/family_services/100_day_kit.php"

Title: Educational Resources.
definition:
"Should [[FNAME]]'s family have questions about special education services, we recommend that they contact the following sources for additional information:

New York State Department of Education: http://www.vesid.nysed.gov/specialed/quality/qaparents.htm
Starbridge: www.advocacycenter.com
The Parent-Educator Resource Library: PERL@boces.monroe.edu"

Title: Educational Testing.
definition: "[[FNAME]]’s academic abilities remain a primary concern.  I would recommend education testing, in order to better characterize [[FNAME]]’s unique pattern of academic strengths and weaknesses, in order to determine specific supports to facilitate ongoing learning.  For more information about educational testing, please contact EnCompass, Resources for Learning at (585) 266-7277.  More information can be found on their website: www.encompassresources.org"

Title: Medication Decision Aid.
definition:
"Since there were questions about the possibility and utility of using medication as a treatment for challenging behaviors, I would recommend that you consult the Autism Speaks medication decision aide, entitled, Autism: Should My Child Take Medicine for Challenging Behaviors.  This tool was designed to help parents and caregivers of individuals with autism spectrum disorders to help make decisions about whether medication might be an option for them.  This tool is helpful for parents who are considering medication for challenging behaviors or who simply want more information about which medications are used.  This decision aid may also help parents to better understand possible risks and benefits of using medication.  Please complete the decision aid and bring it with you to your next regularly scheduled office visit with a developmental pediatrician, nurse practitioner, or psychiatrist.  It may assist your health care provider in assisting you to make an informed decision about medication that matches your personal values, needs and goals for your child.  The medication decision aid can be accessed at the following website:

http://www.autismspeaks.org/science/resources-programs/autism-treatment-network/tools-you-can-use/medication-guide
"

Title: Reviewing Educational Placement Options.
definition:
"I recommend that [[FNAME]]'s {parent/caregiver:28140} reach out to Beth Grier-Leva at the Regional Early Childhood Direction Center to review potential educational placement options for [[FNAME]]. Beth can be reached at (585) 249-7817 or beth_grier-leva@boces.monroe.edu
"

Title: Rochester Child First Network.
definition:
"Services to students with severe language delays who may be on the autism spectrum include a play based relationship building approach to development using many of the ideas suggested in the DIR/floortime model.  RCFN meets regularly to discuss program needs for each student. Goals and strategies are identified using the guidance of SCERTS (“Social Communication Emotional Regulation and Transactional Supports” http://www.scerts.com ) concepts. The SCERTS team is lead by a school psychologist and provides a strong opportunity for professional development and student specific progress monitoring. 

http://rcn4kids.org/special-education/autism/

AUTISM WOMEN'S NETWORK: 

Women with Autism: http://autismwomensnetwork.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Autistic_Women.pdf

Parents: http://autismwomensnetwork.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Parent_Packet.pdf
"

Title: Adaptive Skills at Home.
definition:
"Given [[FNAME]]'s need for a high level of support to complete personal care routines (e.g., hygiene), we discussed the following recommendations:

Use visual checklists to outline what [[FNAME]] needs to complete for [[HIS]] self every day. Separate checklists can be used for various times of day and would list all the steps to each hygiene/personal care routine. For example, write out each step of the shower routine. To get [[HIS]] involved, create these lists collaboratively with [[FNAME]]
A list of chores that [[FNAME]] is expected to do around the house can be posted
Consider using a rewards chart. For example, [[she]] can earn points for getting [[HIS]] self ready, showering when asked, and doing chores. These points can be exchanged for small rewards or privileges 
Helpful resources:
Taking Care of Myself: A Hygiene, Puberty and Personal Curriculum for Young People with Autism, by Mary Wrobel
Making Sense of Sex: A Forthright Guide to Puberty, Sex, and Relationships for People with Asperger’s Syndrome, by Sarah Attwood"

Title: Safety Recommendations.
definition:
"Since [[FNAME]] has a history of impulsive behaviors, little understanding of danger and a history of bolting and elopement (running away), preventative safety strategies are recommended.  [[FNAME]]'s parents may wish to consider the following:

Hiring a locksmith to install special childproof locks at a height that is not reachable by [[FNAME]].  Please take into account how high [[FNAME]] can reach when standing on a chair or other pieces of furniture located near the door.
Consider giving [[FNAME]] an identification bracelet or necklace to wear, so that others know what to do if they find [[FNAME]] in the community.  The identification piece should include name, parent and other emergency contact numbers, diagnosis, and whether [[FNAME]] is verbal or nonverbal.  Sites that sell identification jewelry include:
www.medicalidstore.com
www.mypreciouskid.com/medical-id-bracelent.html
Alert neighbors that [[FNAME]] sometimes runs away from home.  It may be helpful to provide neighbors with an information sheet including [[FNAME]]'s name, your contact information, activities and foods that [[FNAME]] likes (in case there is a wait before you can pick [[HIM]] up), and things that [[FNAME]] is afraid of.  You could also include strategies for basic communication.
Since [[FNAME]] often runs towards water, you may wish to consider enrolling [[HIM]] in a swim class at a local Y or other community organization.  This should not be considered a first line preventative strategy to prevent drowning.  Instead, close supervision, childproof locks, familiarity with the location of pools and ponds in the area are more effective.  The primary goal is to insure that [[FNAME]] is never near water while unsupervised.
Visit the AWAARE website for the Big Red Safety Box, available for free download at awaare.nationalautismassociation.org
"

Title: Strategies to Promote Peer Relationships.
definition:
"[[FNAME]] would benefit from direct instruction in social skills, as well as exposure to social situations that both focus on [[HIS]] interests, and include similarly-aged peers who share those interests. This may be accomplished through the following avenues:

Goals related to promoting social engagement should be incorporated into [[FNAME]]’s updated IEP. For example, these goals may include maintaining conversation or play with peers, responding to social approaches, and participating in group games.


Facilitated recess is often effective in promoting peer interactions for children who are overwhelmed during unstructured time, as it promotes organized group play and sets clear expectations for students. Specifically, facilitated recess involves a) pre-selecting and pre-teaching group games to students, b) clearly communicating the rules of play, and c) teacher presence, to monitor student behavior and encourage cooperative play. This approach can be especially useful for children with ASD who are in the regular education environment because it is geared toward the entire class and is therefore less stigmatizing.



Peer mentorship programs are especially helpful in supporting children with social difficulties in the natural environment while teaching appropriate social skills. For [[FNAME]], working with a kid in [[HIS]] class would be ideal. This individual’s role may include ensuring [[FNAME]] is included in group games, helping [[HIM]] sustain conversations with peers (i.e., by asking him direct questions), and providing classroom assignment/homework help as necessary.

In addition to school-based supports, [[FNAME]] would benefit from participation in structured social skills groups, which focus on explicitly teaching the unspoken social rules and provide practice applying those skills. The following groups may be a good fit for [[FNAME]]. This information is provided for parents to investigate further.


ASSET: http://www.assetrochester.com/ 
AutismUp Boy’s Club: http://autismup.org/classes/boys-club/ 
Center for Social Intelligence: http://www.csi-roc.com/ 
Social Endeavors: http://socialendeavors.net/ 


Structured play dates would involve coordinated, one-on-one interactions between [[FNAME]] and a friend in the context of a time-limited activity. For example, a friend may be invited to bake cupcakes, go to the Science Museum, or play an outdoor game. Parent facilitation of these activities will be important for organizing the interaction and promoting [[FNAME]]’s attention, while the involvement of [[FNAME]]’s interests will help encourage social engagement.  
Continued participation in organized groups (e.g., summer camp) that are based on [[FNAME]]’s interests and strengths will help provide a comfortable environment in which [[HE]] can interact with peers.
Group speech and language sessions can be beneficial for teaching social rules and providing ongoing practice for engaging with peers.
The Lunch Bunch program provides regular opportunities for adult-facilitated conversation among children with a variety of social needs.
"

Title: Anxiety:
definition:
"It is normal for children and adolescents to experience some form of anxiety during the course of their development.  However, when worrying becomes constant and begins to interfere with daily activities, this may be a sign of an underlying anxiety disorder.  A childhood anxiety disorder may involve some of the following symptoms: worrying about things before they happen, worrying about the safety of parents and others, refusing to go to school, clinging to parents, frequent stomach aches, headaches, or other physical symptoms, fatigue and irritability, or difficulty sleeping.

[[FNAME]]’s anxiety negatively affects ability to use some already mastered skills.  [[FNAME]]’s {parent/caregiver:28140} is encouraged to speak to their pediatrician about treatment options. Typically, cognitive-behavioral approaches have been found to be highly successful. If behavioral approaches are either unsuccessful or insufficiently successful, pharmacological treatment as an adjunct is helpful as well. However, I recommend use of non-pharmacological treatment first as this is helpful in developing needed skills.
"

Title: Anxiety.
definition:
"Anxiety was discussed with the family.  We discussed that some degree of anxiety is normal. An anxiety disorder diagnosis is considered when worrying becomes constant and interfere with daily activities. Anxiety symptoms in children may include extreme difficulty separating from parents, excessive fear of an object or situation, excessive shyness or concern about social embarrassment, or uncontrollable worry about daily events. 

We discussed potential treatments including therapy, cognitive-behavioral therapy, self-regulation treatments, and medication.  We discussed the importance of information and resources for families and I recommended the family look at the resources on anxiety available in the family resource center at the Kirch Developmental Services Center Website: www.Golisano.URMC.edu/Kirch"

Title: Anxiety.
definition:
"Aureen Wagner has written extensively about childhood anxiety. She has written books for both children and parents, which could help explain to children what they are feeling as well as some strategies to overcome it and to parents for how to be appropriately supportive while still encouraging their child to try new things.

The following resources may be helpful for better understanding your child's symptoms of anxiety, and for developing treatment strategies that can be used at home:

Web resources
National Institute of Mental Health:
http://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/topics/anxiety-disorders/index.shtml

Anxiety Disorders Association of America:
http://www.adaa.org/

Books for parents of children with anxiety:

Swedo, S.A. & Leonard, H.L. (1998).  Is it just a Phase? How to tell childhood phases from more serious problems.  Broadway Books.

Wagner, A.P. (2005).  Worried no more: Help and hope for anxious children.  Lighthouse Press Inc.

Last, C.G. (2005)  Help for worried kids: How your child can conquer anxiety and fear.  Guilford Publications, Inc.
"

Title: Apraxia:
definition:
"We discussed Childhood Apraxia of Speech (CAS) as a potential etiology of [[NAME]]'s speech difficulties.  CAS is a motor speech disorder characterized by difficulty with motor planning for speech production.  Children with CAS may have difficulty saying sounds and words because their brain have difficulty planning and coordinating the movements of the lips, tongue, jaw, and other facial muscles.  A child with CAS usually knows what he or she wants to say, but struggles to say it due to difficulty with planning and coordinating the oral motor movements.  Muscle weakness or paralysis is not a characteristic of CAS.  Some children with CAS have little or no functional speech, whereas other children are verbal but have problems with intelligibility.   

Further evaluation with a speech language pathologist with specialized knowledge and experience in CAS has been recommended.  This may be available through the school setting, through our center, or through other specialized speech and language programs in the community.  It is often difficult to accurately diagnose CAS until a child is school age or has developed some speech.  It is important to have an accurate diagnosis, as children with CAS tend to do better with intensive, frequent, and individualized therapy that focuses on planning, sequencing, and coordinating the production of speech.  

More information on apraxia is available on the Kirch website: http://www.urmc.rochester.edu/childrens-hospital/developmental-disabilities/conditions/Childhood-Apraxia-of-Speech-CAS/General-Overview-of-Childhood-Apraxia-of-Speech.aspx
"

Title: Recommendations to Address Selective Mutism.
definition:
"1)	Individual therapy with a child psychologist: I recommend that [[FNAME]] meet with a child psychologist regularly to address [[HER]] selective mutism, with the goal of helping [[HER]] to become more comfortable speaking in a variety of social situations. There are a number of behavioral therapeutic approaches that have been found to be effective for children with selective mutism. They include:

•	Contingency management: Providing positive reinforcement (reward) immediately after [[FNAME]] uses a communicative behavior

•	Shaping: Initially reinforcing non-speech communicative behaviors (e.g., nodding, pointing) to eventually build up to or “shape” verbal communication

•	Stimulus fading: Gradually adding or “fading in” the number of people that [[FNAME]] will speak in front through structured social situations

•	Self-modeling: Creating video and/or audio tapes of [[FNAME]] speaking, then playing them for [[HER]] to allow [[HER]] to gradually become more comfortable with hearing [[HER]] self speak in different situations

•	Systematic desensitization: Gradually exposing [[FNAME]] to successively more anxiety-provoking situations, while simultaneously providing relaxation exercises to help manage anxiety

In addition to these behavioral strategies, a child psychologist can work with [[FNAME]] on improving [[HER]] social and communication skills and on building coping mechanisms for anxiety. Given [[FNAME]]’s reluctance to speak to strangers, it will be important for the therapist to work closely with [[FNAME]]’s parents in creating and implementing an intervention plan. 

2)	Social skills training: In addition to individual psychotherapy, [[FNAME]] may benefit from participation in a social skills group, to help foster social and communication skills within a group social situation with [[HER]] peers.

3)	Resources for selective mutism: The following websites provide general information about selective mutism for families.

http://www.asha.org/public/speech/disorders/selectivemutism.htm

http://www.selectivemutism.org
"

Title: House rules and star chart.
definition: "[[FNAME]]'s behaviors are sometimes difficult to manage at home.  I would recommend the implementation of simple house rules.  [[FNAME]]’s *** may want to choose three to four rules for the house (e.g., keep hands to self, touch all pets softly, etc).  These rules should be posted in a highly accessible area, such as on the refrigerator and reviewed with [[FNAME]] several times a day.  [[FNAME]] should be given small rewards, praise or stars on a star chart for following house rules and engaging in more appropriate behavior. A certain number of stickers could earn [[FNAME]] rewards."

Title: Asperger's...What Does It Mean To Me?
definition: "Helpful, non-technical and very readable information for families and children can be found in workbook format at the following:  Faherty, C.  Arlington, TX: Future Horizons Press"

Title: Understanding Behavior.
definition: "I would encourage [[FNAME]]’s {parent/caregiver:28140} to read The Explosive Child by Ross Greene in order to understand the relationship between [[FNAME]]'s current language and coping skills and [[HIS]] emotional and behavior regulation abilities."

Title: Picky Eating.
definition: "The following book provides strategies for dealing with food refusal and limited food choice:  Satter, E.  (1987). How to get your kid to eat but not too much.  Berkeley, CA: Bell Publishing Company."

Title: Sleep.
definition:
"[[FNAME]] has problems sleeping effectively and through the night, so [[HIS]] {parent/caregiver:28140} may find it useful to review the following resource: Owens, J. & Mindell, J. (2005). Take charge of your child's sleep. New York: Marlowe and Company.  

This book provides information about appropriate sleep routines, sleep hygiene, charts for how to track and monitor sleep and when to seek additional help.  Sleep habits and charting will be necessary if further help is required, so this book can aid families getting started.
"

Title: Teaching Flexible Thinking and Behavior:
definition:
"Many of [[FNAME]]’s difficulties with rigid thinking and patterns of behavior seem to pose an obstacle to [[HIS]] success at school and at home. Research has shown that flexibility and goal setting are skills that can be taught, and one way to do this could involve using an evidence-based curriculum such as, Unstuck and On Target! An Executive Function Curriculum to Improve Flexibility for Children with Autism Spectrum Disorders, Research Edition, Cannon, L., Kenworthy, L., Alexander, K., Werner, M., Anthony, L., and Robinson, J. (2011). Baltimore, MD: Brookes Publishing. “Unstuck and On Target!” is a guide for educators to use as a classroom based intervention for students ages 8 to 11 years old. 

A description of this curriculum can be found at: http://products.brookespublishing.com/Unstuck-and-On-Target-P467.aspx 

A companion problem-solving guide called, Solving Executive Function Challenges, was recently released (2014) by the same authors and is designed for use by caregivers, educators, and therapists with children in grades K-8. This problem-solving guide includes specific examples; worksheets that break down tasks into small, achievable chunks, key words and phrases that help kids stay on target; and reproducible visual aids. 

A description of this companion guide to “Unstuck and On Target!” can be found at:
http://products.brookespublishing.com/Solving-Executive-Function-Challenges-P757.aspx
"

Title: Haircuts.
definition:
"Pigtails & Crewcuts is kid-centric salon located in the new Market Commons in Henrietta. They provide a fun, stress-free haircut experience for kids and parents. Walk-ins are welcome or call 585-424-KIDS (5437). More information about Pigtails & Crewcuts can be found at http://www.pigtailsandcrewcuts.com/rochester/
"

Title: Travel:
definition: "http://www.magicalstorybooktravels.com/"

Title: Parent Support.
definition:
"Parent support and information is an important part of comprehensive care of children with Autism Spectrum Disorder.  

The Rochester Regional Center for Autism Spectrum Disorders (Parent support groups, information and resources) 585-273-1613.
Continuing Developmental Services (Autism Family Support Program & Asperger Support Group) Contact: Sheri Zagata 585-224-0960 x 6267.
Parent to Parent of New York State - http://www.parenttoparentnys.org/. I recommended that Brad’s parents reach out to Parent to Parent of New York State (http://www.parenttoparentnys.org/), which may be able to connect them with a family in their area who knows more about local resources and supports.
AutismUp - This is a local support group in Rochester that has a lot of great recreational programs for children with autism spectrum disorders.
Managing Autism Together Today (MATT) - They have events for families of children with autism like monthly family fun nights, mom's and dad's night out, and annual informational and recreational events.
"

Title: Parent Support.
definition: "Parent support and information is an important part of comprehensive care of children with developmental differences.  I recommended that [[FNAME]]’s {parent/caregiver:28140} reach out to Parent to Parent of New York State (http://www.parenttoparentnys.org/), which may be able to connect them with a family in their area or school district who knows more about local resources and supports."

Title: Web-Based Support for Girls and Women with Autism.
definition:
"Autism spectrum disorder often presents differently in females compared to males, so there are many web-based resources that provide information on autism from a female perspective. Note that Kirch Developmental Services Center or URMC does not endorse any program or website, but we provide information for parents to investigate further.
  
Autism Women’s Network (AWN) at http://autismwomensnetwork.org/ - Their goal is to dispel stereotypes and misinformation surrounding an autism spectrum diagnosis. This group shares information to build acceptance and understanding.
http://autismwomensnetwork.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Parent_Packet.pdf
Amaze at http://www.amaze.org.au/girls-and-women-on-the-autism-spectrum/
Tania Marshall, M.Sc. - http://www.taniamarshall.com/index.html"

Title: Web-Based Information.
definition:
"The reliability of web-based information can be difficult to determine.  Some reliable sites of general interest may include:


Autism speaks - http://www.autismspeaks.org 
Centers for Disease Control & Prevention - www.CDC.gov
American Academy of Pediatrics - www.AAP.org
"

Title: Coordinated Adult Health Care.
definition:
"I discussed with [[FNAME]] and his parents the importance of connecting with a health care provider that can provide continuity as he transitions to the adult health care system. One option could include the Complex Care Center, which is affiliated with the University of Rochester Medical Center. More information can be obtained by calling (585) 276-7900 or going to their website at https://www.urmc.rochester.edu/primary-care/practices/complex-care-center.aspx. 
"

Title: Access-VR (Vocational Rehabilitation).
definition: "ACCES-VR assists individuals with disabilities to achieve and maintain employment and to support independent living through training, education, rehabilitation, and career development. I think that ACCESS-VR might be helpful for [[FNAME]] in providing him with some level of support with seeking out employment that is commensurate with his advanced academic standing and his long-term interests. They can find out more about these programs by going to: http://www.acces.nysed.gov/vr/vocational-rehabilitation-services"

Title: Transition Planning.
definition:
"In accordance with the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), an individualized transition plan (ITP) be initiated by the time an adolescent is 14 years of age. For [[FNAME]], a transition plan could include:
  
Formal transition assessment to help select an appropriate and desirable high school and post-high school placement and to identify relevant goals to achieving this outcome.
Transition-related goals for her current placement, including goals related to vocational and life skills (as identified in a transition assessment) that could be incorporated into [[FNAME]]’s current Individualized Educational Program (IEP). Some commonly-targeted areas include Independent daily living, including self-care skills (e.g., personal hygiene, caring for minor medical needs), domestic skills (e.g., completing household chores, cooking for self, using household appliances), and Vocational prerequisite skills"

Title: Transition Resources.
definition:
"The following resources may be helpful for [[FNAME]]’s family in preparing her for transition into adulthood:
  
Transition information and referral line: The Information and Referral Center through The Institute for Innovative Transition may be an valuable resource for Kaylas family.  This service provides information and referrals for individuals with developmental disabilities ages 14-25, their families, school staff, and adult service providers throughout Monroe County.  You may contact our transition specialist, Angela Huss by phone: (585) 273-3783 for information and referral.
  
Transition Website. Please refer to the Institute for Innovative Transition website, which can be accessed at:  Http://www.nytransition.org/. This website provides important information about finding programs and services to help transition your child to an independent adulthood. There is a wide variety of useful information, including:
Think College. Provides information about inclusive college and post secondary educational programs in the region for students with intellectual and developmental disabilities.
Project Search. Provides information about a program designed to offer training and education leading to competitive employment for individuals between the ages of 18 and 21.
Community Engagement. This provides information about workshops that are designed for family members of individuals with developmental differences, as well as professionals who work with them.  Topics include: the nuts and bolts of transition and an overview of the OPWDD and VESID eligibility processes.
  
Books & Guides. The following resources may be helpful for [[FNAME]]’s family in preparing [[HIM]] for transition into adulthood:
Autism Speaks publishes a Transition Toolkit for families of teenagers with ASD.
Preparing for Life: The Complete Guide for Transitioning to Adulthood for Those with Autism and Asperger’s Syndrome, by Jed Baker, Ph.D.
Autism Speaks: https://www.autismspeaks.org/family-services/resource-library/books 
Haddon, M. (2004). The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time.
Robison, J.E. (2007). Look Me in the Eye: My Life with Asperger’s.
Kim, C. (2015). Nerdy, Shy, and Socially Inappropriate: A Guide to an Asperger Life."

Title: Adult Connection at AutismUp.
definition: "Designed for individuals on the autism spectrum, this group meets monthly at AutismUp’s new location in Webster. More information about these meetings and details about registration can be found at: http://autismup.org/autism-support/autismup-connections/."

Title: Square Pegs.
definition: "Square Pegs was founded in 2008 by Deborah Tedone out of her desire to find friends for her daughter.  Over time, Square Pegs evolved into a group dedicated to the Adult with Asperger's Syndrome and is now by and for people with Asperger's. It is a place where adults with Asperger's can gain support without being judged by rules that we didn't make and may not know. Please note that this is not an education group, and all meetings are for people on the autism spectrum only. People without Asperger's who would like to learn more about it may go to Deborah's email address with specific questions at www.deborah11155@hotmail.com. More information can also be found on line by going to: http://www.meetup.com/Square-Pegs-Asperger-s-Support-Group/ "

Title: Health Home Care Management.
definition:
"[[FNAME]]’s mother reported that [[FNAME]] displays a range of intense, frequent behavioral concerns in the home setting. I would encourage his mother to work with Johnathan’s team of providers to consider the possibility of a Health Home Care Management referral for in-home support. More information about the application process can be found here:

http://www2.monroecounty.gov/files/mh/CY%20CM%20Referral%20v12-02-16.pdf 
"

Title: Coordinated Therapeutic Supports.
definition: "I encourage [[FNAME]]’s parents to evaluate and coordinate recommendations across the various providers with whom [[FNAME]] interacts. I think it will be incredibly important to get all his team members on the same page in terms of therapeutic recommendations as he transitions to middle school."

Title: Developing a Communication System.
definition: "I recommend that [[FNAME]]’s parents develop a communication system that works well for them to describe and document what behavioral concerns they observe from [[FNAME]] across settings. In addition, I think it could have value to implement a similar system across providers and school."
